sn21.2:5.1: “Just now, reverends, as I was in private solitude this thought came to mind:
sn21.2:5.2: ‘Is there anything in the world whose changing and perishing would give rise to sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress in me?’
sn21.2:5.4: ‘There is nothing in the world whose changing and perishing would give rise to sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress in me.’”
sn21.2:6.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to him:
sn21.2:6.2: “Even if the Teacher were to decay and perish? Wouldn’t that give rise to sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress in you?”
sn21.2:6.3: “Even if the Teacher were to decay and perish, that wouldn’t give rise to sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress in me. Still, I would think:
sn21.2:6.4: ‘Alas, the eminent Teacher, so mighty and powerful, has vanished!
sn21.2:6.5: If the Buddha was to remain for a long time, that would be for the welfare and happiness of many people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.’”
sn21.2:6.6: “That must be because Venerable Sāriputta has long ago totally uprooted ego, possessiveness, and the tendency to conceit.
sn21.2:6.7: So even if the Teacher were to decay and perish, it wouldn’t give rise to sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress in him.”
